intro: Asperula acuminata, commonly known as the sharp-tipped azalea, is a species of flowering plant in the family Ericaceae. It is native to the mountainous regions of Japan and is characterized by its dense, evergreen foliage and clusters of showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in acidic, well-drained soils and thrives in partially shaded to sunny conditions. Its flowers, which range in color from white to pink and red, bloom in late spring to early summer. Asperula acuminata is often cultivated as an ornamental plant for its aesthetic value and adaptability to various garden settings.
